section.title: Purpose
section.indexterm: exportingOTMBATCH: Translation Memory databases (from command area)
section.p: If you want to export a Translation Memory, using a command typed in your systemâ€™s command area instead of windows might be more convenient.

refsyn.title: Format
refsyn.p: The following syntax diagram describes how you export a Translation Memory from the Windows command line. Note that lowercase letters in a parameter name are optional and need not be typed.

section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: MEMEXP specifies that you want to export a Translation Memory.
mem_file specifies the name (along with the drive and directory) of a file where the Translation Memory specified in memdb is to be exported to. The file must have the extension EXP.

ul.li: ASCII specifies that the encoding of the exported memory should be in ASCII and the format is SGML (EXP).
ANSI specifies that the encoding of the exported memory should be in ANSI and the format is SGML (EXP).
UTF16 specifies that the encoding of the exported memory should be in Unicode (UTF-16) and the format is SGML (EXP).
TMXUTF8 specifies that the encoding of the exported memory should be in UTF-8 and the format is TMX.
TMXUTF16 specifies that the encoding of the exported memory should be in UTF-16 and the format is TMX.

plentry.pd: memdb specifies the name of the Translation Memory that you want to export.
Specifies whether an existing Translation Memory file is to be overwritten when exporting the Translation Memory.

If you specify the parameter in this format, you are not prompted with any message window. If you do not specify any of the /quiet paramaters, a message window pops up whenever an error occurs or when the task has successfully completed.
If you specify this parameter, you are not prompted with any message window. Any error message text is routed to stdout.

section.note: You can type the commands in uppercase, lowercase, or in mixed-case letters. You may not use any wildcard characters, such as an asterisk (*).

example.title: Examples
example.p: The following example shows how to export a Translation Memory using the OTMBATCH command.
In this example, the Translation Memory oldmemo is exported to the file d:\mymemo.exp.
